Option B (Ask the functional manager to provide a resource with the same level of allocation) could potentially be a viable solution to the resource allocation issue, but it is not the best option to pursue first. It may take some time to find and onboard a new resource with the necessary skills and availability, which could further jeopardize the commitment date for the project. It would be more efficient to try to reallocate some of the existing resource's time from the secondary project before seeking out additional resources.

Option C (Remove 20% of allocation of the resource from the secondary project) is the most immediate and practical solution, as it addresses the resource allocation issue directly and allows the resource to focus more of their time and attention on the primary project. This can help to mitigate the risk of insufficient resources and improve the chances of meeting the commitment date.

Selected Answer: D
D. intraorganizational differences

Intraorganizational differences refer to differences or conflicts within an organization. It is possible that the team member is prioritizing their work differently than the project manager because they have different goals, priorities, or perspectives within the organization. For example, the team member may have competing priorities or responsibilities, or they may be working to different deadlines or goals than the project manager. It may also be the case that the team member has a different understanding of their role or responsibilities within the project, or that there are differences in communication or expectations within the team.
